title: clustur
text: clustur developed similar mothur implementation written C++, however differences note. order cluster data, requiring users build sparse matrix (also support phylip files) count table R mothur. objects built can call cluster function. currently support 5 cluster methods mothur: furthest, nearest, weighted, average neighbor opticlust, mothur’s default. methods produce data comparable mothur. speed clustur mothur comparable. show create sparse matrix count table. count table, clustur can produce one , assume abundance sequence one cluster sequences distance matrix.
code: # install via cran install.packages("clustur") # install via github remotes::install_github("SchlossLab/Clustur")

title: clustur
text: mothur used produce tabular count table now produces compressed verion, clustur read formats figure …
code: count_table <- read_count(example_path("amazon.count_table")) #should be a tsv or mothur-native count file count_table_sparse <- read_count(example_path("count_table.sparse.count_table")) #should be a tsv or mothur-native count file

title: clustur
text: mothur produces column/sparse distance matrix Phylip-formatted distance matrix files. clustur read formats figure . return value distance_data memory address. want data frame version distances, can use get_distances(distance_data).
code: distance_data <- read_dist(example_path("amazon_column.dist"), count_table, cutoff = 0.03, FALSE) #> This is a column file. Processing now... distance_data <- read_dist(example_path("amazon_phylip.dist"), count_table, cutoff = 0.03, FALSE) #> This is a phylip file. Processing now...

title: clustur
code: cluster_data <- cluster(distance_data, method = "opti") # this needs to make sure that dist_data and count_table are compatible

title: clustur
code: cluster_data <- cluster(distance_data, method = "furthest") cluster_data <- cluster(distance_data, method = "nearest") cluster_data <- cluster(distance_data, method = "average") cluster_data <- cluster(distance_data, method = "weighted")

title: clustur
text: methods produce list object indicator cutoff used (cutoff), well cluster (clusters) shared (shared) data frames. clusters data frame shows sequence cluster together column cluster identifiers (cluster) column lists indicating identifiers within cluster (identifiers). shared data frame contains columns indicating cluster sample identifiers abundance cluster sample; cluster identifier shared data frame clusters data frame. metrics data frame. OptiClust method also includes metrics data frame, describe optimization value iteration fitting process; data clusters shared taken last iteration. clustur provides getter functions, get_cutoff(), get_clusters(), get_shared(), get_metrics(), demonstrated .
code: clusters <- cluster(distance_data, method = "opti")  get_cutoff(clusters) #> [1] 0.03 get_clusters(clusters) #>       label                        bins   otu #> 85 0.030000 U68618,U68638,U68658,U68620 otu85 #> 88 0.030000 U68663,U68688,U68679,U68665 otu88 #> 87 0.030000        U68641,U68673,U68667 otu87 #> 84 0.030000               U68615,U68680 otu84 #> 86 0.030000               U68631,U68636 otu86 #>  [ reached 'max' / getOption("max.print") -- omitted 83 rows ] get_shared(clusters) #>      label  samples  otu abundance #> 1 0.030000 no_group OTU1         1 #> 2 0.030000 no_group OTU2         1 #> 3 0.030000 no_group OTU3         1 #>  [ reached 'max' / getOption("max.print") -- omitted 85 rows ] get_metrics(clusters) #> $metrics #>      label   cutoff specificity      ppv       ttp  f1score          tn #> 1 0.030000 0.030000    1.000000 1.000000 17.000000 1.000000 4736.000000 #>        mcc       fn       fp sensitivity      npv      fdr accuracy #> 1 1.000000 0.000000 0.000000    1.000000 1.000000 1.000000 1.000000 #>  #> $other_metrics #>      mcc accuracy fdr iter cutoff specificity ppv time f1score tn label tp #>      num_otus fn fp sensitivity npv #>  [ reached 'max' / getOption("max.print") -- omitted 3 rows ]

what: What the Package Does in One Title Case Line
title: What the Package Does in One Title Case Line
text: mothur open-sourced software used analysis ecological data. strong presence use analyzing 16S rRNA gene sequences. mothur plethora features, , clustering based genetic similarity, sequence alignment, taxomic assignment, alpha beta diversity, phylotype analysis. numerous publications using software individuals intuitions alike. plan take advantage power mothur, isolate clustering feature. believe allow scientist work familiar tool give rise creation pipelines utilizing package.

title: What the Package Does in One Title Case Line
text: clustur developed two main reasons: allow developers easily create pipelines mothur code R, give users powerful clustering algorithm mothur without download . mothur built using rcpp, benefits speed c++ usability R. Additionally, since clustur open source, developers can modify package needed. help us continue create high quality packages, allow everyone take advantage foundation already built.

title: What the Package Does in One Title Case Line
code: # install via cran install.packages("clustur") # install via github remotes::install_github("SchlossLab/Clustur")

title: Cluster Description — cluster
code: cluster(distance_object, method, random_seed = 123)

title: Cluster Description — cluster
text: distance_object distance object created using read_dist function. method type cluster wish conduct; opti, furthest, nearest, average, weighted. random_seed random seed wish use, defaulted 123.

title: Cluster Description — cluster
text: list dataframes contain abundance, clustering results.

title: Cluster Description — cluster
code: # Convert Phylip of column file to a sparse matrix  cutoff <- 0.2  count_table <- read_count(example_path("amazon.count_table"))  distance_data <- read_dist(example_path("amazon_column.dist"),                             count_table, cutoff, FALSE) #> This is a column file. Processing now...   # The clustur using one of the 5 methods  # opti  cluster_results <- cluster(distance_data, method = "opti")  # furthest  cluster_results <- cluster(distance_data, method = "furthest")  # nearest  cluster_results <- cluster(distance_data, method = "nearest")  # average  cluster_results <- cluster(distance_data, method = "average")  # weighted  cluster_results <- cluster(distance_data, method = "weighted")

title: Create Sparse Matrix — create_sparse_matrix
text: Given list indexs, j indexes, distances values, can create sparse distance matrix . vector must size.

title: Create Sparse Matrix — create_sparse_matrix
code: create_sparse_matrix(i_index, j_index, distances)

title: Create Sparse Matrix — create_sparse_matrix
text: i_index list indexes, must numeric j_index list j indexes, must numeric distances list distance j index

title: Create Sparse Matrix — create_sparse_matrix
code: # This will return the path to our example file  i_values <- as.integer(1:100)  j_values <- as.integer(sample(1:100, 100, TRUE))  x_values <- as.numeric(runif(100, 0, 1))  s_matrix <- create_sparse_matrix(i_values, j_values, x_values)

title: Get Clusters — get_clusters
code: cutoff <- 0.2 count_table <- read_count(example_path("amazon.count_table")) distance_data <- read_dist(example_path("amazon_column.dist"),                            count_table, cutoff, FALSE) #> This is a column file. Processing now... df_clusters <- cluster(distance_data, method = "opti") clusters <- get_clusters(df_clusters)

title: Read Dist Description — read_dist
code: read_dist(distance_file, count_table, cutoff, is_simularity_matrix)

title: Read Dist Description — read_dist
text: distance_file Either phylip column distance file, sparse matrix. count_table table names given abundance per group. cutoff value wish use cutoff clustering. opti, furthest, nearest, average, weighted. is_simularity_matrix using simularity matrix distance matrix?

title: Read Dist Description — read_dist
code: # Convert Phylip or column file to a sparse matrix  # spMatrix requires the use of the matrix library  i_values <- as.integer(1:100)  j_values <- as.integer(sample(1:100, 100, TRUE))  x_values <- as.numeric(runif(100, 0, 1))  s_matrix <- create_sparse_matrix(i_values, j_values, x_values)    column_path <- example_path("amazon_column.dist")  phylip_path <- example_path("amazon_phylip.dist")  count_table <- read_count(example_path("amazon.count_table"))  data_column <- read_dist(column_path, count_table, 0.2, FALSE) #> This is a column file. Processing now... data_phylip <- read_dist(phylip_path, count_table, 0.2, FALSE) #> This is a phylip file. Processing now... data_sparse <- read_dist(s_matrix, count_table, 0.2, FALSE)

code: count_table <- read.delim(example_path("amazon.count_table"))  count_table_valid <- validate_count_table(count_table)
